About Me


There are two types of engineers in the world: Those who work in their comfort zones and the others who take risk and challenges and constantly keep on learning to make themselves better. I belive myself to be the second kind. I always look forward to staying updated with emerging technology and contribute to projects in making a difference.

My interest in Mechanical Design started in undergrad as a part of Formula Student team where I along with my team designed and implemented an electro-pneumatic gear shifting mechanism at one third of the market available product. My project on numerical simulation of Friction Stir Welding in my junior year also received widespread appreciation and won me $3500 from ASME IDETC/CIE conference in North Carolina, USA. With the vision of expanding my knowledge and howrizons I then joined Purdue University for masters in Aeronautics and Astronautics Engineering with major in structures and minor in controls.

My experience in grad school consists of all phases of product development using composites to achieve a lighter and better performing structure. It consisted of the design phase using CATIA, Solidworkds and then simulating the part using Abaqus followed by manufacturing and testing the part along with experimental validation of simulation. My masters thesis consisted of designing, manufacturing and testing of composite leaf spring of Ford F-150. I have also worked on industrial projects from Ford, John Deere and Nexteer Automotive to design and implement composite parts.

Last but not the least I am interested in electronics and my minor is in control systems. I am proficient with programming microcontrollers (GPIO, UART, SPI, I2C, Interrupts) and assembly level programming. As part of controls project I implemented a cruise control algorithm on a model steam engine. Also, for my embedded systems project I developed a quadcopter from off the shelf components which could perform facial recognition. I now aim to make the quadcopter completely autonomous. I am also passionate about evolving technologies like machine learning and have done course in machine learning by coursera and currently exploring deep learning.

In brief my experience is as follows.




Mechanical Design

Proficient with mechanical design and simulation, protyping using CNC and waterjet, injection molding and testing

Electronics

Familiarity with quadcopters, control systems, raspberry pi, assembly level programming, microcontrollers

Programming

Proficient with Python, MATLAB and C language. Currently exploring deep learning

Composite leaf spring, Ford Motors



Student Incharge : Himal Agrawal
Project Supervisor : Prof. R. Byron Pipes

Abstract : Leaf springs are a part of the suspension system attached between the axle and the chassis of the vehicle to support weight and provide shock absorbing capacity of the vehicle. For more than half a century the leaf springs are being made of steel which increases the weight of the vehicle and is prone to rusting and failure. The current study explores the feasibility of composite leaf spring to reduce weight by designing, manufacturing and testing the composite leaf spring for the required load cases.

Brief Summary :
  • Developed testing fixtures in house using lathe, CNC milling and waterjet for prototype hybrid leaf spring
  • Developed composite layup tool using 5-axis CNC and manufactured glass fiber epoxy composite leaf using autoclave
  • Performed fatigue testing for different load cases and analysed experumental data from load cell and strain gauges
  • The composite leaf spring was lighter by 35% and withstood 1 million cycles without failure
  • Designed tests for small scale fatigue testing as a function of aspect ratio of flexure samples
  • Explored the fatigue properties of composite beams as a function of aspect ration to characterize shear and bending failure


Project Images:


Fig 1. CAD design of fixtures for testing in static and fatigue conditions

Fig 2. Manufactured fixtures for testing using CNC machining, waterjet, lathe

Fig 3. Laser scanning using FARO arm of metal leaf spring to determine geometry

Fig 4. Manufactured mold in 5-axis CNC using laser scanned geometry for composite layup

Fig 5. Trimming of cured composite leaf to required dimensions using wooden trim tool on 5-axis CNC

Fig 6. Layup of stepped flat leaf with silicon dams around to prevent resin flow

Fig 7. Manufactured and assembled hybrid composite leaf spring

Fig 8. Testing apparatus for static and fatigue load cases

Fig 9. Extreme deflection of composite leaf spring to check strength

Fig 10. Experimental attachment of strain gauges to composite leaf spring

Fig 11. Small scale flexure testing as function of aspect ratio to speed up testing

Fig 12. Static flexure failure locations for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 10

Fig 13. Stiffness as function of fatigue cycles for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 10

Fig 14. Flexure fatigue locations for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 10 indicating shear failure from stress concentration

Fig 15. Static flexure failure of samples for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 30

Fig 16. Stiffness vs fatigue cycles for unidirectional samples with aspect ratio 30 - Almost constant, no catastrophic failure

Injection molded pulley, John Deere



Students Incharge : Himal Agrawal, David Kim
Project Supervisors : Josh Dustin, Prof. Jan-Anders Mansson

Abstract : Feasibility of polymer composite material pulley viable for John Deere high power belt drive in tractors was studied. The increase in maintenance difficulties for cast iron pulley being heavy led to the decision to design lighter glass giber reinforced injection molded pulley offering the same stiffness, strength, fatigue properties and resistance to creep. Structural simulations were done from the given loading conditions and the geometry was redesigned to obtain the stresses and strains in the required range and favorable geometry which could be injection molded. Injection molding simulations were then done to find the fiber orientations, warpage, air gaps, weld lines from flow and the effect of these fiber orientations on the final strength of the part.

Brief Summary :
  • Performed literature review and patent search on existing available composite pulleys designs
  • Performed structural simulations for given load cases using Abaqus and redesigned the pulley assembly within the design space to account for stresses and strains
  • Explored the effects of ribbing, hybrid compression molding with carbon fabric and change in geometry on stresses and strains
  • Designed the gating channels, cooling channels, molds and process conditions for an initial injection molding simulation
  • Performed injection molding simulations using Moldex3D to determine flow induced glass fiber orientations and characterize warpage, residual stresses, air traps, weld lines and flow front progress
  • Performed structural simulation in Abaqus with flow induced glass fiber orientations as input to Abaqus model to analyze the effect of fiber orientations on stresses and strains
  • An increase in stresses by 14% was observed due to orientation induced directional strength from glass fibers
  • The final design was lighter by 71% from 105 lb to 30.23 lb


Project Images:


Fig 1. Original geometry of the cast iron pulley and belt assembly

Fig 2. Simplified geometry for large and small pulley for simulations

Fig 3. Stress distribution in cast iron pulley for given loading conditions showing probable failure locations

Fig 4. Modified geometry for stress distribution and stress concentrations due to 6 radial ribs

Fig 5. Modified geometry for stress distribution and stress concentrations due to 12 radial ribs

Fig 6. Modified design 1 for injection molding

Fig 7. Modified design 2 for injection molding

Fig 8. Modified design 3 for injection molding

Fig 9. Modified design 4 for injection molding

Fig 10. Stress distribution for final injection molded design iteration 4 showing probable failure locations for large pulley

Fig 11. Stress distribution for final design iteration 4 showing probable failure locations for small pulley

Fig 12. Injection molding simulation design and workflow

Video 1. Flow front progression in injection molding

Fig 13. Warpage in the large pulley as a result of injection molding

Fig 14. Location of air gaps and weld lines from injection molding simulations

Fig 15. Distribution of fiber orientations in X, Y and Z directions

Fig 16. Mapping of fiber orientations from injection molding using Digimat to Abaqus file for structural simulation

Fig 17. Mapped orientations to abaqus file for large and small pulley from injection molding simulations

Fig 18. Stresses from anisotropic structural simulation accounting for fiber orientation from injection molding which leads to overall 14% increase in overall stresses from isotropic simulations

Fig 19. Principal strains from structural simulation accounting for fiber orientations from injection molding

Composite Control Arm, Ford Motors



Students Incharge : Himal Agrawal, David Kim
Project Supervisor : Mike Bogdanor

Abstract : The project aimed at designing, simulating and manufacturing front lower composite control arm for Ford Motors using compression molding to take advantage of high strength-to-weight ratio of composite materials. A control arm is a hinged suspension link between the chassis and the suspension upright or hub that carries the wheel. The raw material was made by combining two existing advance technologies named Rapid Fabric Formation (RFF) from DuPont and Fibrflex from Fibrtec by the respective companies and offered high flexibility and drapibility for a thermoplastic resin formulation. Transversely isotropic properties for the raw material were determined using experimental tests to populate the material card and further used in Abaqus simulations. Structural simulations were then performed with composite layup using Abaqus for given load cases to satisfy the stiffness requirements. Changes in the geometry were made along with change in composite laminate orientations to study the effect of material orientation and geometric design.

Brief Summary :
  • Characterized the proprietary composite laminate material system for strength by performing tensile tests, shear tests, compressive tests and fracture toughness tests in different directions according to ASTM standards
  • Used MTS machine for loading specimens along with strain gauges and Digital Image Correlation (DIC) to measure strains
  • Analyzed the interpreted the machine data using Python programming language for different material properties
  • Used the material properties as input for composite laminate simulations using Abaqus
  • Studied the effect of change on geometry and material orientations on stresses and strains using Abaqus
  • Performed preliminary compression molding experiments using the proprietary material system


Project Images:


Fig 1. Prepared coupons for tensile testing

Fig 2. Tested specimens to determine strength along different directions

Fig 3. Prepared Mode I fracture toughness samples

Fig 4. Propagation of cracks while testing Mode I fracture toughness

Fig 5. Experimental force-displacement data indicating propagation of crack at load drop

Fig 6. Specimen failing in bending rather than crack propagation due to high bending strength

Fig 7. Fixture for performing IITRI compression test

Fig 8. Strain gauges samples for compression test for measuring compressive modulus

Fig 10. Experimental setup for calculating Mode II fracture toughness

Steering Column, Nexteer Automotive



Student Incharge : Himal Agrawal
Project Supervisor : Mike Bogdanor

Abstract : The work aimed at developing new composite steering columns that take advantage of the favorable stiffness-to-weight ratio of carbon fiber composites to deliver enhanced performance. The first phase involved the homogenization of material properties for laminate consisting layers of unidirectional pultrusion material, continuous filament mat and biaxial carbon fabric. A sensitivity study was then done to find the change in natural frequencies as a function of pultruded angle, thickness and different material properties using Abaqus. A python code coupled with Abaqus was developed to automate the process of changing material properties and writing required results to a user specified file eliminating the use of graphical user interface and manual labor.

  • Initially performed natural frequency analysis using Abaqus for provided original model using Abaqus without composites to find first 3 natural frequencies
  • Fixed the errors in the Abaqus model for successfully finding the natural frequencies of the column
  • Found the homogenized material properties for laminates consisting of pultrusion layer, continuous filament mat and biaxial carbon fabric using classical laminate plate theory
  • Used the material properties in Abaqus model to find the change in natural frequencies with change in material properties
  • Performed a sensitivity study to study change in natural frequencies as a function of different material properties and analyzing the part having the maximum effect
  • The work was automated using Python coding coupled with Abaqus which made necessary changes to the Abaqus input file, ran the simulations, extracted the results and wrote them to a specific file without the need of graphical user interface and manual labor


Project Videos :



Video 1 : 1st Natural Frequency

Video 2 : 2nd Natural Frequency

Video 3 : 3rd Natural Frequency

Manufacturing of Composites



Manufacturing of Composites : Understanding of composite manufacturing is essential to develop a complete understanding for designing a composite structure. The course taught by Prof. R. Byron Pipes at Purdue University aimed at examining the phenomenon involved like Darcy flow, permeability and compaction of fiber beds, thermoset reaction kinetics, polymer viscosity, property measurements, heat transfer, void formation, polymer physical properties, anisotropic composite properties, and residual behavior. The course developed theoretical and experimental skills in the following mentioned areas.

  • Polymer Transitions (Glass transition temp, degree of cure, visco-elastic behavior)
  • Cure Kinetics and Rheology
  • Darcy’s Law
  • In and out of autoclave manufacturing (VARTM, Oven, Autoclave)
  • Thermal residual stresses and deformation
  • Percolation and transverse squeeze flow
  • Compression molding


Project Images:

Characterization of Composites



Characterization of composites : With the advancement in technology to reduce manufacturing costs composites have found their way in the industries due to their high strength-to-weight ratio. Working with composites it is imperative to understand the direction dependence of properties of composites. The course of Characterization of Composites taught by Prof. R. Byron Pipes at Purdue University aimed at developing the mathematical understanding of directional behavior of composites along with lab experiments to validate the theoretical knowledge. The course developed theoretical and experimental skills in the following mentioned areas.

  • Micromechanics
  • Anisotropic Elasticity
  • Failure Theories
  • Microscopy
  • Directional tensile testing
  • In plane shear and off axis tensile strength
  • CTE of lamina and Laminates
  • Open Hole Tension
  • Mode I and Mode II fracture toughness
  • Free edge effects
  • Compression failure

Formula Student Team, IIT Kharagpur



Students Incharge : Himal Agrawal, Vraj Parikh, Siraj Modiwala
Project Supervisors : Prof A.R. Mohanty, Prof. C.S. Kumar, Prof. S.K. Panda

Abstract : TeamKart is the formula student team of IIT Kharagpur which designs, fabricates, manufactures and tests Formula prototype sports car. As a part of the transmission subsystem, I along with other members of the subsystem designed and implemented an electro-pneumatic gear shifting mechanism from the existing manual pull-push rod shifting mechanism for better efficiency and driver ergonomics.

The work involved studying the existing technologies available and modifying to the required needs. The design and selection of several components such as high pressure air source, solenoid valve, air regulators, two way actuators and electronic wiring with an Arduino was done. The components were bought assembled together to obtain a fully functional prototype of the shifting mechanism. Calculations were done to calculate the torque requirement for shifting along with actuator lengths and mounting locations. Finally the solenoid value was actuated by pressing the up-shift or down-shift button with the algorithm planned in an Arduino.

Project Images and Videos:


Fig 1. Designed and manufactured formula student car by the team

Video 1. Electro-pneumatic shifting

Video 2. Electro-pneumatic shifting

Modelling of Friction Stir Welding



Student Incharge : Himal Agrawal
Project Supervisors : Prof. Rahul Jain, Prof. S.K. Pal

Project Details : Friction stir welding is a solid state joining process that uses frictional heat generated by a rotating tool to join materials. The tool is non-consumable and rotates while rubbing against different pieces of materials which causes the frictional heat to soften the materials and the rotation of the tool mixes the materials resulting in joining or welding when cooled. It is a high strain rate complex deformation process and in the study the process was studies as a CFD phenomenon to predict heat generation and temperature distribution with high viscosity fluid as a function of strain rate. The viscosity of the fluid around the tool was low due to high strain rate and helps in visualization of material mixing. The results obtained by the simulation were experimentally validated from the temperature data obtained from the thermocouple.

Outcomes of the project:
  • Successfully modelled friction stir welding with 95% accuracy compared to experimental results
  • The work was selected to be presented at IDETC/CIE conference as a part of “Innovative Design Simulation Challenge” organized by ASME and was awarded $3500 in the category “Best Utility in Commercial Category”


Project Images:


Fig 1. Experimental setup on 2-ton NC controlled FSW machine

Fig 2. Geometric model of workpiece and boundary conditions

Fig 3. Numerical results for temperature distribution for 1200 rpm

Fig 4. Cross-sectional view of temperature distribution at 1200 rpm

Fig 5. Shoulder and Pin bottom heat flux distribution

Fig 6. Strain rate distribution for various rotational speed at 60 mm/min (a) 900 rpm (b) 1200 rpm (c) 1500 rpm

Quadcopter



Students Incharge : Himal Agrawal, Nieves Brunet, Joseph Yanos
Project Supervisor : Prof. Vijay Raghunathan

Project Details : The purpose of the class project was to develop a remotely controlled aerial vehicle to perform facial recognition. The prototype developed was fully functional and used a transmitter to relay live video feed on laptop which is used to perform facial recognition in real time.

The first step included was to design the quadcopter and select the required electronic components. A custom frame was manufactured by designing in CATIA and then using layup of carbon fiber fabric and oven curing and then cutting the required geometry using a waterjet. After performing required background research on quadcopters and available technology EMAX 2300 KV motors, BLHeli 32 bit electronic speed controllers (ESC), Naze32 flight controller, power distribution board, battery, transmitter and camera were chosen. This required analysis of the total weight of the quadcopter to ensure the thrust provided by the motors would be sufficient. Additionally, the power draw of the motors was considered to ensure the battery could support a long enough flight time.

The components were integrated together with correct wiring and attached with the frame. The microcontroller which acts like a brain for the quadcopter was configured to calibrate the motor, configure the transmitter settings and PID tuning. In parallel to creating the quadcopter, the code for facial recognition was developed using the open source resources like openCV. The code was put together to analyze a live video feed and perform facial recognition. From a set of still photos the code was trained to recognize the people for which it was trained.

The quadcopter was fully functional and performed facial recognition for required targets. Further efforts are being made to make the quadcopter fully or semi-autonomous along with object detection using Lidar.

Project Videos :



Video 1 : Built quadcopter flight test

Video 2 : Facial Recognition using Quadcopter

Cruise Control



Student Incharge : Himal Agrawal
Project Supervisor : Prof. Peter Meckl

Project Details : The project of implementing the cruise control algorithm using PID for a steam engine was done as a part of the course Microprocessors in electro-mechanical systems. The class objectives were to develop detailed understanding in the areas mentioned below with lab experiments for practical implementation.

  • Digital Logic
  • Microcontroller components and programming
  • Assembly language programming
  • Subroutines using assembly language and C
  • Programming peripherals using assembly language and C
  • Programming GPIO using assembly language and C
  • erial communication (UART)
  • Programming interrupts using assembly language and C
  • Timer interrupts
  • Mixed assembly language and C language programming
  • Digital to Analog conversion
  • Analog to Digital conversion
  • Continuous and discrete PID control system
  • Effects of sampling and aliasing in PID
  • Digital filters
  • Peripherals (Timers, DMA, I^2C, GPIO)
  • Types of stepper motors and its programming
  • Optical encoders

The final project of the course included implementing the PID cruise control algorithm using all the knowledge from the course material and lab experiments on a model steam engine. The tasks included writing a PID algorithm in an interrupt and running the interrupt at a given frequency to implement the algorithm on the engine. The PI controller values were found by system characterization for a given damping ratio and settling time. The model was also simulated in Simulink to verify and compare the system response. The controller was then implemented on the STM32 microcontroller for the digital implementation of the system. The cruise controller performed as expected by maintaining the speed within a required settling time and achieved all project deliverables.

Project Images:


Fig 1. Complete experimental setup including 4-stroke engine, air supply, air filter and regulator, microcontroller, motor and optical encoder

Fig 2. Model engine operated by air pressue with attached encoder to measure rotational rpm

Programming



Programming : Skilled with programming languages C and Python. Completed the python course offered by Purdue University to earn a certification. Familiar with the python concepts of functions, lists, tuples, sets, dictionaries, regular expression, matplotlib, class and inheritance, NumPy and Pandas.
Passionate about evolving technologies like machine learning and completed Machine Learning course offered by Coursera to obtain 100% grade. Gained knowledge and programming skills in the following mentioned areas.

  • Linear and Logistic Regression
  • Multi class classification
  • Neural network – Forward propagation and backpropagation
  • Regularized regression and Bias vs Variance
  • Support Vector Machines
  • Percolation and transverse squeeze flow
  • K-means Clustering and Principal Component Analysis
  • Anomaly Detection and Recommender Systems

Currently exploring deep learning as time permits.
